author: By Adam Rasgon
title: A Covid Christmas comes to Bethlehem.
description: The pandemic has put a damper on Christmas at the place where it is said to have all begun: the town of Bethlehem in the West Bank.
content: The pandemic has put a damper on Christmas at the place where it is said to have all begun: the town of Bethlehem in the West Bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: With Alibaba Investigation, China Gets Tougher on Tech
description: Jack Ma and other entrepreneurs prospered under Beijing’s laissez-faire attitude toward the business side of the internet. The dynamic is shifting as the companies have grown in power.
content: China’s internet giants came to dominate segments of the world’s No. 2 economy because Beijing’s authoritarian government largely looked the other way while they grew and grew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: How Much Herd Immunity Is Enough?
description: Scientists initially estimated that 60 to 70 percent of the population needed to acquire resistance to the coronavirus to banish it. Now Dr. Anthony Fauci and others are quietly shifting that number upward.
content: At what point does a country achieve herd immunity? What portion of the population must acquire resistance to the coronavirus, either through infection or vaccination, in order for the disease to fade away and life to return to normal?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: When the Pandemic Ends, Don’t Put Off Any More Adventures
description: The future of travel will involve fewer selfies from Icelandic spas.
content: In early March, I was walking around the most magical place on earth — Disney World’s Magic Kingdom in Orlando, Fla. — asking guests why they were comfortable being at a theme park with thousands of strangers and sticky-fingered children as a virus that we then believed to be passed through touch was spreading throughout the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Dear Comrades!’ Review: When the Party Line Becomes a Tightrope
description: With a bureaucrat as the central character, the film at times takes on a bleakly comic tone as it fills in the circumstances surrounding a massacre.
content: In 1962, Soviet government forces violently suppressed a strike against rising food prices in Novocherkassk, a city in the Don River region of southern Russia. It would be decades before the event received acknowledgment from official sources. A K.G.B. report, revealed after the fall of the Soviet Union, said that 20 bodies from the “liquidation” had been “buried in various places.” But for years, the slaughter was obscured from public view. Bodies? What bodies?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Jerry Harris Pleads Not Guilty in Child-Pornography Case
description: The 21-year-old fan favorite on the Netflix series “Cheer” pleaded not guilty to multiple felony charges, including soliciting sex from minors.
content: Jerry Harris, the 21-year-old breakout star of the Netflix series “Cheer,” has pleaded not guilty to federal child pornography charges and accusations that he solicited sex from minors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: When Needs Are Acute, Going an Extra Mile at the Holidays
description: Gift drives via video conference. Deliveries from the food bank. Nonprofits adapted to continue providing for people in need.
content: In Decembers past, millions of families made gift drives part of their holiday preparations, a way to share with others as they shopped for their own loved ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: First a Trial Run, Then the Real Thing
description: After six months of dating, Chelsea Graham and Matthew Kocurek moved in together for a week, calling it a “practice run.” They’ve lived together ever since.
content: It took Chelsea Graham and Matthew Kocurek four years to to get to their first date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer and Benedict Carey
title: Coronavirus Variant Is Indeed More Transmissible, New Study Suggests
description: Researchers warn that the British variant is so contagious that new control measures, including closing down schools and universities, may be necessary.
content: A team of British scientists released a worrying study on Wednesday of the new coronavirus variant sweeping the United Kingdom. They warned that the variant is so contagious that new control measures, including closing down schools and universities, might be necessary. Even that may not be enough, they noted, saying, “It may be necessary to greatly accelerate vaccine rollout.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: An Irish boy writes to Pfizer requesting a vaccination for Santa, and receives a reply from its C.E.O.
description: When six-year-old Callum Thornhill heard that Pfizer had developed a coronavirus vaccine, he wrote to the company with an urgent request: to prioritize Santa Claus.
content: When six-year-old Callum Thornhill heard that Pfizer had developed a coronavirus vaccine, he wrote to the company with an urgent request: to prioritize Santa Claus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: Hospital Workers Start to ‘Turn Against Each Other’ to Get Vaccine
description: “I am so disappointed and saddened that this happened,” a New York hospital executive wrote to his staff after workers who did not have priority cut the line for the vaccine.
content: At NewYork-Presbyterian Morgan Stanley Children’s Hospital, one of the most highly regarded hospitals in New York City, a rumor spread last week that the line for the coronavirus vaccine on the ninth floor was unguarded and anyone could stealthily join and receive the shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong and Cao Li
title: With Money, and Waste, China Fights for Chip Independence
description: Beijing’s drive to free itself from reliance on imported semiconductors has lifted start-ups and big firms alike. Some have flamed out. But there has been progress.
content: Liu Fengfeng had more than a decade under his belt at one of the world’s most prominent technology companies before he realized where the real gold rush in China was taking place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: N.F.L. Week 16 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
description: The Colts are favored on the road in Pittsburgh, the Rams will try to stay alive in Seattle and a frozen matchup between Tennessee and Green Bay should still have plenty of offense.
content: The N.F.L. playoff picture should come into sharp focus this weekend, with several division titles and wild-card spots likely to be decided. There will be games on Friday, Saturday, Sunday and Monday, and while a few of them are irrelevant, most can have an impact on the standings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Your Name Engraved Herein’ Review: When Love Is All You Can See
description: The filmmaker Patrick Liu keeps the focus on the two young men in this Taiwanese drama and blurs the rest.
content: The love story in the touching, simple Taiwanese drama “Your Name Engraved Herein” unfolds at a Catholic high school for boys. It’s 1987, shortly after the end of nearly four decades of martial law, but before the easing of social repression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: A Christmas Eve ‘Travel Nightmare’: Snow, Flooding, Maybe Tornadoes
description: On a holiday when health experts admonished people not to travel, the weather brought its own hazards across much of the country.
content: A nasty winter storm slammed the eastern United States on Christmas Eve, pushing drivers off the roads and threatening to spoil the plans of holiday travelers and last-minute shoppers in a season already dampened by the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Wonder Woman 1984’ Review: It’s Not About What We Deserve
description: The sequel to the 2017 hit finds Diana Prince, a.k.a. Wonder Woman, pining for love and saddled with a movie unworthy of her.
content: When Wonder Woman first hit the big screen in 2017, the possibilities for the character felt endless. After 76 years without a blockbuster to call her own — she muscled into comics, bracelets flashing, in 1941 — she had made it, becoming a box-office sensation. And, yay! The movies love sexpot vixens vamping in fetish wear (meow) and nice girls simpering in the wings, so it was relief that this Wonder Woman was neither. She was sovereign, powerful and lightly charming, and even when the movie had teasing fun with her it took the character, her mighty sword and cultural significance seriously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Wehner
title: The Forgotten Radicalism of Jesus Christ
description: First-century Christians weren’t prepared for what a truly inclusive figure he was, and what was true then is still true today.
content: “Get used to different.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: The New Words for Our New Misery
description: Doomscrolling, mask-hole, Zoom fatigue and more from the pandemic lexicon.
content: Of all the personal development opportunities presented by quarantine — knitting, baking sourdough, starting a TikTok — there is none so user-friendly as talking to yourself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus
title: ‘You Checked Tesla the Most’: Robinhood Recaps From a Volatile Year
description: And you thought your Spotify Wrapped was a bummer.
content: In 2020, wild fluctuations in the stock market caused by the pandemic turned millions of people into opportunistic investors. After stocks plunged in March, experienced traders and Nasdaq novices poured their dollars into buzzy tech companies like Tesla and Zoom, as well as businesses bludgeoned by Covid restrictions, including airlines, restaurants and cruises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Sometimes a Broken Laptop Can Be a Good Thing
description: Ugene Bynum, a software engineer, made a lasting impression on Stacy Prather, who had sought his help to fix her computer.
content: Ugene Bynum knew he might not be able to fix Stacy Prather’s broken laptop, but when she and her godmother knocked on his Philadelphia front door asking for help in the fall of 2016, he didn’t turn them away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: For a Defeated President, Pardons as an Expression of Grievance
description: President Trump’s grants of clemency to convicted liars, corrupt congressmen and child-killing war criminals are a way to lash out at a system that he believes has treated him and his friends unfairly.
content: The statement announcing the latest raft of presidential pardons was officially attributed to the White House press secretary, but it bristled with President Trump’s own deep-seated grievances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: The Start of a New Chapter in Their Favorite Bookstore
description: LaMarr Coles proposed to Stephanie Williams at Greedy Reads in Baltimore, where a few months earlier they had made their relationship official.
content: If Stephanie Williams didn’t know she was going to marry LaMarr Coles III after their first phone call, she sensed she might after their first date. And she definitely knew it two weeks in, at the end of date No. 3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: For the European Union, It’s a Pretty Good Deal
description: The Brexit pact preserves crucial E.U. principles like the single market, and lets the bloc look ahead to its future without Britain.
content: BRUSSELS — The European Union emerges from fraught negotiations with Britain over its exit from the bloc with a sense of satisfaction — that it has maintained its unity and its core principles, especially the integrity of the single market of now 450 million consumers that is the foundation of its influence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Black Voters Want President Biden to Take a Cue From Candidate Biden
description: In his victory speech, the president-elect said of Black voters: “You’ve always had my back, and I’ll have yours.” Many of those voters are watching to see what he does in office.
content: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. went to the Royal Missionary Baptist Church in South Carolina in late February, before the state’s presidential primary, and listened as the Rev. Isaac J. Holt Jr. delivered a message of encouragement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: In a disrupted holiday season, even Bethlehem is quieter than usual.
content: Despite Dr. Anthony Fauci’s claim of having vaccinated Santa Claus and NORAD’s annual wink-wink tracking of his sleigh, this is clearly an interrupted holiday season from pole to pole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah and Michael Levenson
title: Lawsuit Accuses Tony Robbins of Discriminating Against Employee Who Got Covid
description: A sales executive who was placed on a ventilator while in a coma says she was denied accommodations to work from home as she recovered.
content: Tony Robbins, the life coach and motivational speaker, discriminated against one of his employees by refusing to grant her the accommodations she needed to work from home after she contracted a debilitating case of Covid-19 in the spring, according to a lawsuit filed Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Mancuso and Lisa Prevost
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom house in Tarrytown, N.Y., and three-bedroom apartment in Stamford, Conn.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Carey
title: A Parent Trap? New Data Offers More Dire View of College Debt
description: In a separate loan program, more parents are loading up on debt, often in greater amounts than their children.
content: If you have children nearing college age, you’ve probably heard a lot about student loans. Americans owe $1.7 trillion in college debt, an amount that grows every year. And while colleges differ greatly in their propensity to load up families with debt, it has been hard to identify the biggest offenders — until now.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Spending Drops as Income Falls, Spurring Alarm
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 24, 2020.
content: “We know that things are going to get worse. The question is how much worse.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: With Olympics Postponed, U.S. Marathon Champion Decided to Have a Baby
description: When competitive running events for 2020 largely disappeared, Aliphine Tuliamuk and her partner saw the opportunity to have a child before the next Olympics.
content: Aliphine Tuliamuk was the surprise winner of the Olympic Trials marathon on Feb. 29.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Trucks Stuck at U.K. Port Begin Moving, but Many Face a Roadside Christmas
description: France closed the border to help limit the spread of a coronavirus variant. With the border now reopened, testing thousands of drivers and clearing the backlog of freight will take some time.
content: LONDON — Trucks began boarding ferries in Dover on Thursday to cross the English Channel for the first time in four days, a step toward ending a thousands-deep traffic jam that piled up at the border after France banned crossings from Britain to limit the spread of a coronavirus variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: An Oscar Winner Made a Khashoggi Documentary. Streaming Services Didn’t Want It.
description: Bryan Fogel’s examination of the killing of the Saudi dissident Jamal Khashoggi had trouble finding a home among the companies that can be premier platforms for documentary films.
content: Bryan Fogel’s first documentary, “Icarus,” helped uncover the Russian doping scandal that led to the country’s expulsion from the 2018 Winter Olympics. It also won an Oscar for him and for Netflix, which released the film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: On Working With Congress, Biden Predicts Success Where Predecessors Failed
description: The president-elect insisted that his skills and his history would enable him to secure bipartisan support for bold initiatives.
content: WASHINGTON — When he takes office next month, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will confront a sharply divided Congress where many Republicans argued that his election was fraudulent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: Disadvantaged Students More Likely to Be Learning Remotely, Study Finds
description: Research from Columbia University suggests that less effective instruction will widen the achievement gap.
content: WASHINGTON — Disadvantaged students are much more likely than others to be engaged in remote schooling during the coronavirus pandemic, increasing the risk that less effective instruction will widen the achievement gap, according to the first comprehensive analysis of attendance patterns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Black Doctor Dies of Covid-19 After Complaining of Racist Treatment
description: “He made me feel like a drug addict,” Dr. Susan Moore said, accusing a white doctor of downplaying her complaints of pain and suggesting she should be discharged.
content: [To read more stories on race from The New York Times, sign up here for our Race/Related newsletter.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Emmanuel Macron, Free of Covid-19 Symptoms, Leaves Isolation
description: The French leader, who suffered from a cough, headaches and fatigue after contracting the coronavirus, has remained active during his quarantine period, his office said.
content: PARIS — A week after he first tested positive for the coronavirus, President Emmanuel Macron of France has stopped isolating himself because he no longer shows symptoms, a statement from the Élysée Palace, his official office, said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: For Ijeoma Oluo, Books and Bedtime Are a Perfect Combination
description: "Lately, I’ve been able to find a few minutes to read in bed each night after my family has gone to sleep and it’s been absolutely heavenly.”
content: “Lately, I’ve been able to find a few minutes to read in bed each night after my family has gone to sleep,” says the author of “Mediocre,” “and it’s been absolutely heavenly.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: A 2020 retrospective.
content: Seeking moments of light, we found solace in rescue animals, banana bread and — for the messy among us — the joy of not tidying up. We watched an awful lot of television, some of it excellent. We cooked, and cooked, and cooked (see below) — and then ordered takeout. Sometimes, we just played The Sims 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: The Surprising Places in New York City Where Trump’s Support Grew
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. won President Trump’s hometown handily. But a deeper look at election data suggests a surge in support for the president in some districts.
content: In the months leading up to the election, as the restaurant where she has worked for 18 years in Corona, Queens, struggled to survive, Juliana Rodriguez wavered over her choice for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: A freight traffic logjam eases at British ports, and other news from around the world.
description: Trucks began boarding ferries in Dover on Thursday to cross the English Channel for the first time in four days, a step toward ending a thousands-deep traffic jam that piled up at the border after France banned crossings from Britain to limit the spread of a coronavirus variant.
content: Trucks began boarding ferries in Dover on Thursday to cross the English Channel for the first time in four days, a step toward ending a thousands-deep traffic jam that piled up at the border after France banned crossings from Britain to limit the spread of a coronavirus variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Luke Broadwater
title: Answering Trump, Democrats Try and Fail to Jam $2,000 Payments Through House
description: In a brief bit of political theater, the House majority leader opened the chamber for business to ask for unanimous consent to accede to President Trump’s request for larger checks.
content: WASHINGTON — The fate of $900 billion in pandemic aid will remain in limbo over the Christmas break after House Democrats tried and failed on Thursday to more than triple the size of relief checks, then adjourned the House until Monday, when they will try again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernard Schwartz
title: The Doodles of Great Writers
description: Nabokov left a butterfly, Roxane Gay drew an elephant and Isabel Allende offered a caricature of herself — a few gems hidden in the guest book of the 92nd Street Y’s Unterberg Poetry Center.
content: When writers exit stage right after a reading at the 92nd Street Y’s Unterberg Poetry Center, they may feel satisfaction or relief, elation or the sense of a job well done. Writers being writers, they may feel that they did not deserve the audience’s applause — or that they deserved more of it. What happens next is always the same. I ask them to sign our guest book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: In a Pandemic Fairy Tale, a Garden Leads to a Magical Friendship
description: A 4-year-old girl coping with the loneliness of the pandemic created a tiny garden, and kindled an unlikely friendship with an enchanted neighbor who moved into her tree.
content: Kelly Kenney was taking a late-night walk to clear her thoughts in her Los Angeles neighborhood this spring when a colorful pinwheel caught her eye. She stopped and found herself gazing down at an elaborate fairy garden at the base of a tree, complete with painted rocks and tiny trinkets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Conversation With Joe Biden
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: “It will be the first priority, the second priority and the third priority — to deal with Covid and bring down the spread and bring down the death rate,” President-elect Joe Biden told me during a phone call yesterday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: A Slow Day at the Restaurant
description: Billy Ouska makes his New York Times Crossword debut, with plenty to spare.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I’m really enjoying all these new voices in the Crossword. That doesn’t mean that I don’t appreciate our veteran constructors, but I see it as similar to the Scouts song “Make New Friends”: “Make new friends, but keep the old. One is silver, the other is gold.” There’s room for everyone, and new constructors reveal new perspectives on things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Pinocchio’ Review: An Enchanting Yet Befuddling Adaptation
description: Matteo Garrone, who directed the searing true-crime drama “Gomorrah,” takes a whack at Carlo Collodi’s classic tale.
content: This new cinematic imagining of Carlo Collodi’s classic fantasy tale is alternately enchanting and befuddling. Roberto Benigni plays the woodworker Geppetto — before you recoil at the prospect, let’s note that the frequently over-the-top actor is relatively restrained and appropriate throughout. At the movie’s opening, the character is in such dire straits that he finds fault with the furniture at his local osteria, offering to fix it in exchange for a meal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: Seeing the Met’s Greatest Hits as Artists Painted Them
description: Goya, Caravaggio, Rubens, Velázquez and more are in skylit splendor in the European galleries. And the museum is acknowledging the shaping force on art of colonialism, slavery, the disenfranchisement of women.
content: “In a dark time, the eye begins to see,” the poet wrote. And after the dark, dark time we’ve been through, this year’s winter solstice, marking the start of slow climb back into light, may carry more metaphorical weight than usual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Mixing Politics and Romance
description: Sarah Lockman and John Collins met two years ago at a political roast and benefit in Delaware, where she serves as a state legislator.
content: For Sarah Lockman and John Collins, the pivotal moment in their relationship occurred in a most unusual place: high atop the staircase of Mr. Collins’s new home in St. Michael, Md., where he and Ms. Lockman struggled for three hours to carry a futon down the stairs this past January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikhil Kumar
title: How Does an 83-Year-Old Jesuit End Up in Prison?
description: Father Stan Swamy spent decades fighting for the rights of India’s marginalized people. In October, Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government imprisoned him under antiterrorism laws.
content: NEW DELHI — What I remember most is the way my grandfather struggled with everyday things. Eating, drinking, even smiling in response to a joke or a favorite song. The disease froze his muscles, turning the majestically expressive face of an aging patriarch into a mask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Death comes in multiples in a close-knit valley on the Mexican border.
description: Days after her Thanksgiving feast was prepared, served and eaten, Maribel Rodriguez tried to muster the will to unpack the tree, lights and decorations of boisterous Christmases past.
content: Days after her Thanksgiving feast was prepared, served and eaten, Maribel Rodriguez tried to muster the will to unpack the tree, lights and decorations of boisterous Christmases past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski and Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Silly Season: How British Pantomime Looks From Across the Pond
description: Thanks to streaming, two American critics got to binge a bunch of the traditional holiday spectacles. They’re amused, and confused, by what they saw.
content: In a year of theatrical catastrophes, English pantomime looked to be one more. Big-heart, big-joke, big-budget extravaganzas, these shows depend on live audiences like few others. Staged at Christmastime and performed throughout much of the Anglophone world, pantos take classic fairy tales and zhuzh them up with famous guest stars, topical humor and song parodies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘Brother & Sister’ and ‘The Resisters’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: BROTHER & SISTER: A Memoir, by Diane Keaton. (Vintage, 192 pp., $16.) Made up of journal entries, letters, poetry and collages — of which Keaton’s younger brother made hundreds as he descended into mental illness — this memoir charts the ebb and flow of a close sibling relationship. Elisabeth Egan, who interviewed the Oscar-winning actress for our Inside the List column, called it “brave.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley and Amy Haimerl
title: These Businesses Thrived as Others Struggled to Survive
description: As the pandemic ravaged small businesses across America, some were surprised — and conflicted — about their success.
content: Small businesses were devastated in 2020. They have pivoted so frequently to deal with state-mandated shutdowns, new customer needs and pandemic safety protocols that many aren’t sure what direction they’re facing anymore. Nine months into the coronavirus crisis, more than a quarter remain closed, at least temporarily, according to data from Opportunity Insights, a research group at Harvard University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Parents of ‘Balloon Boy’ Are Pardoned by Colorado’s Governor
description: Richard and Mayumi Heene were accused of concocting a hoax after their 6-year-old son was feared to have floated away in a balloon in 2009. The boy was found safe at home.
content: In 2009, the authorities chased a silver helium balloon resembling a U.F.O. as it soared over Northern Colorado, fearing that a young boy was trapped inside. The frantic rescue effort unfolded on live television, but when the balloon landed, there was no boy inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Arora and Karan Deep Singh
title: Bollywood, Reeling From the Pandemic, Shifts to Streaming
description: India’s film industry, which relied on theatrical releases, is experimenting with going straight to streaming services such as Amazon, Netflix and Disney’s Hotstar.
content: “Coolie No. 1” has all the hallmarks of a big Bollywood film: colorful costumes, larger-than-life sets, foot-tapping music and a melodramatic story about a man who pretends he has a twin to woo the woman of his dreams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Mackenzie
title: She’s a Chess Champion Who Can Barely See the Board
description: Like the fictional Beth Harmon in “The Queen’s Gambit,” she’s trying to find a way to get to Russia to compete. Unlike Beth, she’s blind.
content: Have you heard this story before? Girl has rough start in life, discovers chess. She becomes a United States champion. She studies Russian. And now she needs to find a way to get to Russia to play chess, because she can’t afford it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zoë Beery
title: Your Most-Played Song of 2020 Is … White Noise?
description: Ambient music, background noise and calming sound effects have soothed the anxious, isolated and sleep deprived this year.
content: The soundtrack to Maya Montoya’s year was white noise. Specifically, a track on Spotify called “Celestial White Noise”: three whole hours of warm, soothing fuzz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: The Tiny Victories That Got Parents Through 2020
description: It’s been a rough year. Let’s celebrate the little wins.
content: In a year filled with chaos and uncertainty, at least there were moments of closeness, levity and relief for parents, despite the pandemic and other disasters. We asked, and you delivered the tiny victories that got you through this wretched year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: People Are Dying. Who Do We Save First With the Vaccine?
description: With limited doses available, and a pandemic claiming more lives every day, a complex moral calculus has begun. Five thinkers weigh the choices ahead.
content: In mid-December, before a key vote by an advisory panel for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, a public debate flared up over what might well be the most momentous policy decision of 2021: how to distribute the Covid-19 vaccine. This particular fight centered on how to balance the vaccination of seniors (who die from the coronavirus at much higher rates than younger people) against that of essential workers (who, because they come into contact with many people over the course of any given day, risk getting sick themselves and becoming superspreaders).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: A last-minute Brexit scramble.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul R. Kolbe
title: With Hacking, the United States Needs to Stop Playing the Victim
description: The U.S. also uses cybertools to defend its interests. It’s the age of perpetual cyberconflict.
content: There is indignant howling over what is surely Russia’s role in infiltrating, again, the networks of the U.S. government and corporations — this time through a tainted software update by the company SolarWinds. Politicians of both parties have called it a virtual act of war. “America must retaliate, and not just with sanctions,” Senator Marco Rubio said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: How Did Mistletoe Get Into the Treetops?
description: Before someone hung it up in your home, some animal had to get it into the canopies where it thrives to this day.
content: It’s unclear what trendsetter first hung up mistletoe. Some blame the ancient Greeks, who kissed under the plants during harvest festivals. Others pin it on first-century druids, who might have decorated their homes with them for good luck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Promising Young Woman’ Review: Courting Dangerous Liaisons
description: Carey Mulligan stars in this feminist revenge thriller that too often backs away from its potentially searing setup.
content: A hard candy with a sour center, “Promising Young Woman” turns sociopathy into a style and trauma into a joke. Embodying both, Cassandra (Carey Mulligan), 30, a medical school dropout still living with her concerned parents (Jennifer Coolidge and Clancy Brown), is a weekday barista and a weekend huntress. Her prey is two-legged, but single-minded: men who equate a woman’s inebriation with consent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Britain and E.U. Scramble to Reach Brexit Deal Before Christmas
description: With a deadline closing in fast, negotiators were racing to strike a deal, with an agreement said to be imminent.
content: LONDON — Britain and the European Union appeared on the cusp of a landmark post-Brexit trade agreement on Wednesday, with negotiators in Brussels all but resolving the final issues, a person briefed on the talks said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christy Harmon, Laura O'Neill, Jolie Ruben, Amanda Webster, Jessie Wender and Michael Cooper
title: Our Favorite Arts Pictures of 2020
description: Celebrities, artists, musicians and actors at home, outdoors and in lockdown: The stories behind the pictures that defined our year.
content: The magenta glow of an exhibition outside the Guggenheim Museum, whose white spiral was off-limits to art lovers. The deserted grand staircase of a Metropolitan Opera silenced by the pandemic, its Sputnik chandeliers with no crowds to illuminate. Movie buffs, barred from cinemas, enjoying films at least semi-communally at a drive-in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Soul’ Review: Pixar’s New Feature Gets Musical, and Metaphysical
description: This inventive tale stars Jamie Foxx as a jazz musician caught in a world that human souls pass through on their way into and out of life.
content: In about 100 jaunty, poignant minutes, “Soul,” the new Pixar Animation feature, tackles some of the questions that many of us have been losing sleep over since childhood. Why do I exist? What’s the point of being alive? What comes after?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: A garden leads to a magical friendship.
description: Kelly Kenney was taking a late-night walk to clear her thoughts in her Los Angeles neighborhood this spring when a colorful pinwheel caught her eye. She stopped and found herself gazing down at an elaborate fairy garden at the base of a tree, complete with painted rocks and tiny trinkets.
content: Kelly Kenney was taking a late-night walk to clear her thoughts in her Los Angeles neighborhood this spring when a colorful pinwheel caught her eye. She stopped and found herself gazing down at an elaborate fairy garden at the base of a tree, complete with painted rocks and tiny trinkets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: A Century After Phony Flu Ads, Companies Hype Dubious Covid Cures
description: Musical medicine? Corona-fighting herbs? “Human beings haven’t changed all that much,” a marketing professor says of the similarities between ads from 1918 and recent months.
content: With a pandemic raging, a spate of ads promised dubious remedies in the form of lozenges, tonics, unguents, blood-builders and an antiseptic shield to be used while kissing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: For Christmas, Pastors Offer Comfort and Joy in a Somber Season
description: “The darkness seems pretty dark at the moment,” said one minister, who will preach about hope in the face of fear.
content: When the Rev. Timothy Cole learned he had Covid-19 in early March, it was the first known case of the virus in Washington. Mr. Cole, the rector of Christ Church Georgetown, was hospitalized for three weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mercedes Lilienthal
title: Rolling Homes That Make an R.V. Look Palatial
description: Two couples have spent years on the road with about 50 square feet or less to call home. It takes wanderlust — and a seriously concise kitchen plan.
content: What if you went on a road trip, and never came back?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: The ‘Trump Bump’ for Books Has Been Significant. Can It Continue?
description: As a new administration looms, publishers have snapped up another crop of forthcoming Trump books by prominent journalists and pundits.
content: In the past four years, publishers have released more than a thousand books about Donald J. Trump. Authors have examined seemingly every facet of his persona, in works about his presidency, family, political rise, business dealings, reality-TV career and golfing habits. The body of work is so voluminous that there’s even a book about all the Trump books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Roger Berlind, 90, Dies; Broadway Impresario Who Amassed 25 Tonys
description: He played a role in producing more than 100 plays and musicals. And while he kept an eye on the bottom line, he could be seduced by sheer artistry.
content: Roger Berlind, who produced or co-produced more than 100 plays and musicals on Broadway, including such critical and box-office hits as “The Book of Mormon,” “Dear Evan Hansen,” “City of Angels” and revivals of “Guys and Dolls” and “Kiss Me, Kate,” died on Dec. 18 at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Dave Philipps
title: Backlash Over Leniency at West Point After 73 Cadets Are Accused of Cheating
description: The revelations — and the academy’s handling of them — have prompted a debate about integrity, rehabilitation, and what it means to be a cadet.
content: It is engraved in a stone monument on the grounds of the U.S. Military Academy at West Point: “A cadet will not lie, cheat, steal, or tolerate those who do.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: The Sidney Awards
description: A hard year produces great writing.
content: This has not been a great period for free expression. The range of socially acceptable opinion has shrunk, as independent-minded journalists and experts have been eased out of their jobs at places ranging from New York magazine to Boeing and Civis Analytics for saying unorthodox things. The esteemed scholar James R. Flynn wrote a book called “In Defense of Free Speech” which was in turn canceled by his publisher for being too controversial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Emily Cochrane, Astead W. Herndon and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s Attack on Coronavirus Relief Divides G.O.P. and Threatens Recovery
description: From the campaign trail in Georgia to Capitol Hill, President Trump’s demand for changes to the $900 billion pandemic relief plan upended political and economic calculations.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s denunciation of the $900 billion coronavirus relief deal drove a wedge through the Republican Party on Wednesday, drawing harsh criticism from House Republicans and threatening the delivery of unemployment checks, a reprieve on evictions and direct payments to struggling Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘The Dissident’ Review: A Murder for Power
description: Bryan Fogel’s new documentary about the killing of Jamal Khashoggi underlines the disregard for human rights when money and geopolitics are at play.
content: A cinematic retelling of the murder of the Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi requires no embellishments. The raw facts are sinister and dramatic in themselves, involving a gruesome killing inside a consulate in a foreign country, an ambitious prince intolerant of dissenters and a kingdom with far-reaching financial clout. Yet Bryan Fogel’s new documentary, “The Dissident,” goes the extra mile, deploying an aggressive score, frenzied editing and C.G.I. elements to drive home the pathos of Khashoggi’s story and what it reveals about Saudi Arabia’s insidious machinery of surveillance and repression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Makela
title: Dear Santa, Why Are You Behind Plexiglass?
description: All over the country, the annual Christmas ritual for children looks and feels different this year.
content: Santa Claus is different this year. He wears a mask and his lap is mostly off limits. Outdoors he waves to boys and girls from a safe distance, and indoors a sheet of plexiglass separates him from his visitors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Aimee Nezhukumatathil Wants You to Get Some Fresh Air
description: In her best-selling essay collection, the veteran poet offers a cynicism-busting perspective on nature.
content: WONDER WOMAN It’s not every day that pets come up during a phone interview, but the subject is relevant when you’re talking to Aimee Nezhukumatathil, whose illustrated essay collection, “World of Wonders,” doubles as a love letter to little creatures. It turns out she shares her home with a small, mostly Chihuahua-based mutt named Haiku. “He’s a really teeny dog and I’m a nerdy poet, so there you go,” she explains. “Unfortunately he has a little bit of pandemic weight on him, so now we joke that he’s a haibun, which is a larger form of Japanese poetry.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meryl Cates
title: Dancing by Herself: When the Waltz Went Solo
description: Grete Wiesenthal, a ballet-trained Viennese dancer, made the waltz modern and a vehicle for solo expression.
content: Waltzing can go on for hours in an endless rotation, as partners coiled in each other’s arms whisk around a brimming dance floor. It requires a significant amount of physical contact, which is why the waltz was considered somewhat of a guilty pleasure until the early 19th century, when its popularity finally overthrew propriety. And now during the coronavirus pandemic close partner dancing raises eyebrows again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: 5 Takeaways From the Post-Brexit Trade Deal
description: Britain and the European Union spent months negotiating the terms of commercial relations after Dec. 31.
content: Britain and the European Union struck a trade deal on Thursday, setting the terms of their commercial relations after Britain completes its hard-fought split from the European Union on Dec. 31.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Schwartz
title: Want a Nice Dinner Out? Your Hotel Room Awaits
description: Restaurateurs and hoteliers are teaming up to create private dining experiences that allow guests to get out of the house, but limit their exposure to others.
content: It had been six months since Nick Bayer and his wife had been on a date. But with freezing temperatures gripping Philadelphia and indoor restaurant service banned, dinner in a tent wasn’t appealing. So instead of sitting outdoors at the Walnut Street Cafe, a local restaurant, they opted for an elegant meal served in a hotel room that had been converted into a private dining space.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Christmas Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.
content: In the fantasy version of a December evening, we would sweep in off West 54th Street, down the staircase and into the cozy, enveloping glamour that always makes Feinstein’s/54 Below feel like it’s ready for its close-up. We would slide into a booth and order a little something lovely. Then the long-running cabaret series “Sondheim Unplugged” would begin — one more shimmering perk to spending the holidays in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Tompkins
title: Facing Deportation, They Fled to the Safety of a Church. Now They are Free.
description: A Jamaican couple spent nearly two and a half years inside Philadelphia churches, isolated even further by the pandemic. This month, U.S. immigration officials relented.
content: Hand in hand, Oneita and Clive Thompson danced out of the Tabernacle United Church in Philadelphia, their fists raised in victory. The Jamaican couple had spent nearly two and a half years living in churches to avoid deportation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: How much herd immunity is enough?
description: At what point does a country achieve herd immunity? What portion of the population must acquire resistance to the coronavirus, either through infection or vaccination, for the disease to fade away and life to return to normal?
content: At what point does a country achieve herd immunity? What portion of the population must acquire resistance to the coronavirus, either through infection or vaccination, for the disease to fade away and life to return to normal?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Stimulus, Brexit, Storm:Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman and Emily Schmall
title: Pakistani Court Orders Men Released in Daniel Pearl Case
description: A detention order had been applied to four men accused in the American journalist’s abduction and murder even after their convictions were overturned.
content: KARACHI, Pakistan — A Pakistani court on Thursday ordered the release of four men being held over the 2002 abduction and killing of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, arguing that they had been acquitted months ago, and that their continued detention was illegal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Farber
title: Leslie West, ‘Mississippi Queen’ Rocker, Is Dead at 75
description: He rose to fame with Mountain, which Rolling Stone called a “louder version of Cream” — a band Mr. West idolized. One of the group’s first gigs was Woodstock.
content: Leslie West, whose meaty guitar riffs and snarling lead lines powered the hit band Mountain through “Mississippi Queen” and other rock anthems of the 1970s, died on Wednesday in Palm Coast, Fla. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Japan’s Prime Minister Apologizes Over Scandal Tarring His Term
description: Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga said he had unintentionally misrepresented the facts around a political scandal after prosecutors announced they would seek to punish a former aide to Shinzo Abe.
content: TOKYO — Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga of Japan apologized on Thursday for what he said were unintentionally false statements about a political spending scandal that has tarred the first months of his administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Social Q’s: Covid Christmas Edition
description: The holidays are always complicated and especially so this year.
content: My three sisters and I have been doing Secret Santa with our kids for years. Each child picks a cousin’s name. They love exchanging gifts! This year, I told my sisters that my family would not be joining them for Christmas because of Covid but that we’d still like to be part of the Secret Santa. (I could drop off our gifts in advance.) But after following up, I learned that my sisters decided to limit the exchange to cousins who would be there in person. I am hurt that my kids will be excluded and, worse, that my sisters made this decision without discussing it with me. They said the cousins like to watch each other opening gifts, so it made no sense to include my two. Thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Brexit Is Finally Done, but It Already Seems Out of Date
description: The idea of an agile “Global Britain” was an effective sales pitch. But that was before President Trump and other populists began erecting barriers to trade.
content: LONDON — It took 11 grueling months for negotiators from Britain and the European Union to hammer out the terms of a post-Brexit trade deal. But in many respects, the deal is already four and a half years out of date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Franklin
title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan
description: This week’s listings are in Brooklyn Heights, Long Island City and Turtle Bay.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Jeannie Morris, Trailblazing Chicago Sportscaster, Dies at 85
description: She was a rare woman in broadcast sports journalism when she began her career in the late 1960s, but she helped pave the way for the many women who followed.
content: Jeannie Morris, a television sports reporter, was in the visitors’ dugout in 1972 before a game at Comiskey Park in Chicago when the Hall of Fame hitter Ted Williams, who was managing the Texas Rangers, ordered her out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: The Most Popular Listings of November
description: The most popular listings include a pair of super-expensive houses, two sunny, Manhattan apartments, and a chic condo in Montreal, Canada.
content: The most popular listings on The New York Times’s Find a Home site in November include a pair of super-expensive homes, two sunny, Manhattan apartments, and a smartly designed three-bedroom condo in Montreal, Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Trump Warns Iran of Retaliation After Attacks on U.S. Embassy in Baghdad
description: The administration and military officials blame Tehran for recent rocket attacks in Iraq, adding to the growing tensions between the United States and Iran.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump warned Iran on Wednesday that he would hold it accountable “if one American is killed” in rocket attacks in Iraq that the Trump administration and military officials blamed on Tehran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Sweet Breakfast With a Secret
description: A hidden layer of crumbs makes these muffins feel like the best coffee cakes.
content: The best muffins are the ones that veer into cupcake territory. Buttery, rich and occasionally glazed or iced, a muffin is intended to make eating cake acceptable for breakfast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer and Benedict Carey
title: Additional modeling shows the British variant’s high transmissibility.
description: A team of British scientists released a worrying study on Wednesday of the newly discovered coronavirus variant sweeping Britain. They warned that the variant was so contagious that new control measures, such as closing down schools and universities, might be necessary. Dr. Nicholas Davies, the lead author of the study, said that the findings “are pretty convincing that more rapid vaccination is going to be a really important thing for any country that has to deal with this or similar variants.”
content: A team of British scientists released a worrying study on Wednesday of the newly discovered coronavirus variant sweeping Britain. They warned that the variant was so contagious that new control measures, such as closing down schools and universities, might be necessary. Dr. Nicholas Davies, the lead author of the study, said that the findings “are pretty convincing that more rapid vaccination is going to be a really important thing for any country that has to deal with this or similar variants.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Charm City Kings,’ ‘Babyteeth’ and Other Hidden Streaming Gems
description: You may have missed these under-the-radar movies this year. Now’s your chance to catch up.
content: As 2020 sputters to its conclusion and film critics devise their year-end best-of lists (Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott’s are here), the customary consensus begins to form around a handful of widely beloved titles: “First Cow,” “Never Rarely Sometimes Always,” “Beanpole,” “Martin Eden,” and the like. But a wide variety of at-home viewing options made this a particularly rich year for independent cinema, so in that spirit, this month’s selection of hidden streaming gems focuses solely on the films of 2020 — from heartfelt indie dramas to searing documentaries to, yes, a thriller about a man and his posterior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: Why You Can’t Meet God Over Zoom
description: Virtual services are inadequate — but I keep going.
content: When our congregation, Church of the Savior, moved to online services some nine months ago, our family tried to keep things normal. We had the children dress in nice Sunday clothes, though we would be watching via screen instead of entering a sanctuary. We arranged the chairs in the living room to look like pews. We tried to follow along, bowing at the right times and crossing ourselves at the right moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: What We’re Looking Forward To in 2021
description: Amid the challenges of 2020, there are reasons to be optimistic heading into the new year.
content: To say that 2020 was stressful is an understatement, what with a pandemic that the world hasn’t yet emerged from, a sharply divisive U.S. presidential election whose controversies have yet to ebb, social unrest over vast inequalities … need we go on?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Trump Gives Clemency to More Allies, Including Manafort, Stone and Charles Kushner
description: It was the second wave of pardons and commutations by the president in two days, showing his willingness to use his power aggressively on behalf of loyalists.
content: President Trump doled out clemency to a new group of loyalists on Wednesday, wiping away convictions and sentences as he aggressively employed his power to override courts, juries and prosecutors to apply his own standard of justice for his allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: A Middle-Aged Christmas
description: The meaning of Christmas nostalgia in the middle of life’s journey.
content: Marching toward middle age is a sequence of older-than moments, when you realize that you’ve passed some famous age that seemed impossibly distant as a child. First you pass the prodigies: Older than William Pitt the Younger when he became prime minister, older than Donna Tartt when she published “The Secret History,” older than Alexander the Great when he conquered Persia. Then come the athletes: When you reach your later 30s, you realize that if you had actually become a baseball star, you would now be Kirk Gibson gimping to the plate, an old man in baseball years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma and Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Biden Is Expected to Expand U.S.-India Relations While Stressing Human Rights
description: Most experts agree that China will be the driving force behind how India’s relationship with Washington changes in a Biden administration.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has significantly invested in its relationship with India over the past four years, seeing the country as a crucial partner in counterbalancing the rise of China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Influencers May Face Fines as China Tackles Obesity and Food Waste
description: According to a new government report, more than half of the country’s adult population is either overweight or obese. Chinese officials have vowed to address the problem with a campaign.
content: HONG KONG — More than half of China’s adult population is either overweight or obese, according to a new government report released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: As the end of this endless year approaches, we find ourselves in a retrospective mood: Out with the old, in with the even older! Our recommended books this week cast an eye back on the Bolshevik Revolution and the seeds of the Cold War (“The Lenin Plot,” by Barnes Carr); and on the little-known role that people fleeing slavery played in American foreign and domestic policy before the Civil War (“South to Freedom,” by Alice L. Baumgartner); and on the ways that Winston Churchill’s larger-than-life legacy continues to shape British politics to this day (“The Churchill Myths,” by Steven Fielding, Bill Schwarz and Richard Toye).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Manuela Andreoni
title: In a lonely time, a teacher in Brazil creates a ‘hugging kit’ for her students.
description: While much as the pandemic has been a story of devastation and loss, it has also been one of resilience — of individual people, families and entire communities not only surviving a deadly threat but seeing in the moment a chance to serve others. Some even dare remind us that joy is still a possibility. We asked our correspondents around the world to share stories from this year that speak to the strength of the human spirit, and to how disruption can bring out the best in us.
content: While much as the pandemic has been a story of devastation and loss, it has also been one of resilience — of individual people, families and entire communities not only surviving a deadly threat but seeing in the moment a chance to serve others. Some even dare remind us that joy is still a possibility. We asked our correspondents around the world to share stories from this year that speak to the strength of the human spirit, and to how disruption can bring out the best in us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Sullivan
title: Andrew Sullivan on the War Within Conservatism and Why It Matters to All of Us
description: Edmund Fawcett’s “Conservatism” is a sweeping history that reaches deep into the past but with startling relevance for the present.
content: CONSERVATISMThe Fight for a TraditionBy Edmund Fawcett
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: Why China Turned Against Jack Ma
description: The Alibaba chief paid for pushing back against Beijing. But the shift in attitude also speaks to a growing wealth gap and diminished opportunities for the young.
content: In China, Jack Ma is synonymous with success. The English teacher turned internet entrepreneur is the country’s richest person. He founded Alibaba, the closest thing Amazon has to a peer and rival. After Donald J. Trump was elected president in 2016, Mr. Ma was the first high-profile Chinese person he met with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: A Covid Christmas Comes to Bethlehem
description: Every Christmas, the quiet West Bank town of Bethlehem becomes a bustling hub for pilgrims, tourists and dignitaries. Not this year.
content: BETHLEHEM, West Bank — The Church of the Nativity was closed, and most souvenir shops shuttered. Hotels that are usually sold out months in advance were deserted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nellie Bowles and Annie Karni
title: Brad Parscale Fell From Trump’s Favor. Now He’s Plotting a Comeback.
description: Mr. Parscale, President Trump’s former campaign manager, was angry after he was demoted last summer, and wanted out of politics. That didn’t last long. He is starting a new political data company.
content: Brad Parscale was sounding upbeat. He has a new company and, he believes, a brighter future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derek Watkins
title: How We Reported on Pollution in New Delhi Through Two Children
description: The idea was simple: compare the difference in exposure to unclean air among wealthy and poor families by tracking two kids for a day. Pulling it off was trickier.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: A Flying Elephant, a Teacher’s Hugs: 12 Tales of Pandemic Resilience
description: The virus has been crushing spirits around the world, but some people refuse to be bowed. Here are their stories.
content: . . . wrote the third grader. A few months into quarantine, his teacher, Maura Cristina Silva, could tell that her vivacious students were starting to buckle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marilyn Stasio
title: ‘Eyes Open. Hit First. Move Fast. Stop When He’s Dead.’
description: The Butcher’s Boy may no longer be a professional hit man, but he hasn’t forgotten how to kill, as we learn in Thomas Perry’s new novel, “Eddie’s Boy.”
content: The Butcher’s Boy — the professional killer we first met in Thomas Perry’s debut novel back in 1982 — hasn’t lost his extremely sharp edge. In his fourth outing, EDDIE’S BOY (The Mysterious Press, 274 pp., $26), Michael Schaeffer, as he now calls himself, shows how far he has come in the world since his early career as a hit man. (“He’d had a long life for a man in his line of work,” he acknowledges, with some satisfaction.) Schaeffer is living uneventfully with his English wife in Bath when his previous life intrudes with a vengeance. Four armed men have come to kill him, and while their corpses are now safely stowed in a big black sedan, Michael has no idea who sent them. Some mob family must have called for his assassination — but which one?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Britain and E.U. Reach Landmark Deal on Brexit
description: The trade agreement comes after months of negotiations, and still leaves critical details to be worked out.
content: LONDON — Britain and the European Union struck a hard-fought trade agreement on Thursday, settling a bitter divorce that stretched over more than four years and setting the terms for a post-Brexit future as close neighbors living apart.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 24 Hours Inside a Brooklyn Hospital: An Update
description: In the spring, with permission from staff, patients and their families, we shadowed one doctor for a day to get a sense of what it is like on the front lines of the pandemic.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Ali Watkins
title: Her Father Had a Theory About Her Killing. Then Came the Arrest.
description: Ola Salem’s body was found in a Staten Island park last year. Her father said she had talked about being followed on the highway.
content: When Ola Salem’s body was discovered in a park on Staten Island in October 2019, her friends and relatives were left grasping for an explanation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘DNA’ Review: Digging for Roots
description: After her immigrant grandfather dies, a woman wants to reclaim her ethnicity.
content: “DNA,” the fifth feature from the French actress and filmmaker Maïwenn, opens in clamor and closes in calm. In between is a journey taken by Neige (played by Maïwenn and inspired by her own life) as she moves away from the fractious embrace of her extravagantly maladjusted family and toward her Algerian roots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: In the Rio Grande Valley, Death Has Become a Family Affair
description: Christmas will be quieter in the Texas borderlands, where aunts and uncles, grandparents and adult siblings often live under the same roof. That closeness let the coronavirus ravage families.
content: EDINBURG, Texas — Days after her Thanksgiving feast was prepared, served and eaten, Maribel Rodriguez tried to muster the will to unpack the tree, lights and decorations of boisterous Christmases past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: No More All-Nighters!
description: How to navigate an office where all-night work sessions are celebrated, tips for transitions and what to do with a charismatic but abusive colleague.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Preston
title: Eight-Armed Underwater Bullies: Watch Octopuses Punch Fish
description: The solitary cephalopods occasionally join a hunting party with fish, then lash out for reasons that scientists are studying.
content: The first time Eduardo Sampaio saw an octopus wind up and punch a fish, “I burst out laughing,” he said. That was a problem because he was scuba diving in the Red Sea and nearly choked on his diving regulator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Trump’s Most Disgusting Pardons
description: Blackwater mercenaries committed a massacre. Now they’ll go free.
content: The youngest victim of the 2007 massacre in Baghdad’s Nisour Square, committed by Blackwater mercenaries whom Donald Trump pardoned on Tuesday, was a 9-year-old boy named Ali Kinani.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Stella Tennant, Aristocratic British Model, Is Dead at 50
description: Noble lineage, classic beauty and punk attitude combined in a model who stood at fashion’s apex for three decades.
content: Stella Tennant, the unimpeachably aristocratic model and inspiration to designers like Karl Lagerfeld and Gianni Versace, died on Tuesday in Duns, Scotland. She was 50.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priyanka Mattoo
title: How the Virus Stole Christmas
description: For immigrant families from India, the holidays come closest to the long, riotous wedding seasons in the homeland.
content: LOS ANGELES — Many years ago, when my brother and I were just out of the house, my parents entered a raffle and won a Christmas tree. It was fake, 12 feet tall and covered in hundreds of Raggedy Ann dolls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophia June
title: What Are You Paying For in a $300 Chess Set? Mostly the Knights
description: The horses in higher-end wooden sets must be hand-carved, a long, specialized process to make sure all four are exactly the same.
content: If you bought a wooden chess set after watching “The Queen’s Gambit,” the price you paid was most likely dictated by just four pieces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Covid-19 Patient Is Bludgeoned to Death in California Hospital
description: The victim, an 82-year-old man, was hit with an oxygen tank by another patient with whom he was sharing a room, the authorities said.
content: An 82-year-old man who was being treated for Covid-19 at a hospital north of Los Angeles was bludgeoned to death with an oxygen tank last week by his roommate, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maeve Higgins
title: I Will Never Bail on My Friends Again
description: It’s been a year of loneliness and isolation. In 2021, we’ll celebrate.
content: I finished television during the pandemic and started on movies. Now I’m almost finished with those, too! My hips have locked in a supine position and my eyes are dry as a bone, but I persist. What else is there to do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Mexico Begins Vaccinations Amid Virus Surge
description: Mexico is the first country in Latin America, a region hard hit by the coronavirus, to begin delivering vaccines. A head nurse at a Mexico City hospital was the first to get a shot.
content: MEXICO CITY — Mexico began its coronavirus vaccination campaign on Thursday, becoming the first country in Latin America to do so, and providing a sliver of hope to the population amid a roaring resurgence of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel, Eric Lipton and Jesse Drucker
title: Behind Trump Clemency, a Case Study in Special Access
description: Philip Esformes was sentenced last year to 20 years for Medicare fraud. Then a well-connected organization supported by his family weighed in with the White House.
content: Philip Esformes acquired a $1.6 million Ferrari and a $360,000 Swiss watch and traveled around the United States on a private jet, a spending spree fueled by the spoils from what federal prosecutors called one of the largest Medicare fraud cases in history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Miss the N.Y.C. Subway? These Radio Plays Bring It Back to Life
description: A new audio series from Rattlestick Playwrights Theater imagines the bustle of the trains before the pandemic — one story and one station at a time.
content: Jasmine, a student at Brooklyn College, sprints across the platform to catch an idling train. She had lingered on the No. 2 a second too long, distracted by a performer-cum-mystic doling out free advice that felt eerily relevant. Now she was moments away from missing her transfer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘News of the World’ Review: Tom Hanks Does the Strong, Silent Type
description: The star can’t help but bring decency to Paul Greengrass’s lean, efficient western set in 1870s Texas.
content: Nowadays, if you want a selection of news stories culled from various publications, you can use a cellphone app. But if you lived in Texas in 1870, you could pay a dime to watch Tom Hanks shuffle through a stack of newspapers and read selected articles aloud. It seems like a much better deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Petr Cech Is in His Comfort Zone: In the Middle of Everything
description: For the recently retired goalkeeper, a role as Chelsea’s technical director is appealing because of how different it is from playing.
content: LONDON — Petr Cech does not watch a lot of television. Switching his brain off, by his own admission, does not come easily to him. He has always preferred, he said, to fill every minute of his day, not just with work and family but with a moderately intimidating litany of pastimes and projects. Settling down on the sofa counts, to his mind, as time wasted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: A Christmas Unlike Any Other
description: Thursday: Wishing you comfort, safety and rest.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Britain Gets a Boost With a Brexit Trade Deal, but Challenges Loom
description: The free-trade pact would help both sides avoid tariffs, but Britain would still face economic costs from being outside the European Union.
content: LONDON — The British economy got a jolt of confidence Thursday as Britain and the European Union announced an agreement that will define their future trading relationship after years of negotiations since the country voted in 2016 to leave the bloc.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: ‘Schitt’s Creek’ Fans Arrive in Goodwood
description: The hamlet that was the backdrop for the hit television series Schitt’s Creek has become a pilgrimage site for fans, to the joy and consternation of locals.
content: GOODWOOD, Ontario — Joe Toby was recently giving a young couple a tour of his workshop, when the man sprinkled rose petals on the concrete floor and got down on one knee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joyce Cohen
title: They Wanted Something Rundown, With Potential. Which Apartment Did They Choose?
description: As they planned their Zoom wedding, one young couple went on the hunt for a Manhattan home that was nice — but not too nice — in a convenient location with some outdoor space. Here’s where they landed.
content: As they planned their Zoom wedding, one young couple went on the hunt for a Manhattan home that was nice — but not too nice — in a convenient location with some outdoor space. Here’s where they landed.

author: By Jonathan Corum and Carl Zimmer
title: How the Sinovac Vaccine Works
description: Using inactivated coronaviruses to teach the immune system.
content: Using inactivated coronaviruses to teach the immune system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The 2020 Baseball Trivia Extravaganza
description: This test is not for the faint of heart, or the casual fan. See how your knowledge of the sport holds up in our fourth annual holiday baseball quiz.
content: This test is not for the faint of heart, or the casual fan. See how your knowledge of the sport holds up in our fourth annual holiday baseball quiz.

title: Let’s Start Over
description: Vaccines are coming. Donald Trump is going. Sometime in 2021, life will look a lot more normal. But it won’t be the same.
content: Vaccines are coming. Donald Trump is going. Sometime in 2021, life will look a lot more normal. But it won’t be the same.

title: Britain and E.U. Reach Long-Awaited Brexit Trade Deal
description: Britain and the European Union reached a landmark trade agreement on Brexit after 11 months of negotiations and just a week before a year-end deadline.
content: Britain and the European Union reached a landmark trade agreement on Brexit after 11 months of negotiations and just a week before a year-end deadline.

title: Corrections: Dec. 24, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 24, 2020.
content: An article on Tuesday about presidential pardons misstated the status of a meeting between Erik Prince and a Russia-sanctioned banker in the Seychelles. The meeting took place during the 2017 presidential transition; it was not the case that it did not occur.
